steps.title: Drink more water.
steps.content: Drink more water. Dehydration can cause your body to extract as much water as it can as foods move through your digestive tract, producing dry, hard stool. Drinking enough water will soften your stool and help things move along more easily. [1] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Doctors sometimes recommend 2.7 liters (for women) or 3.7 liters (for men) of water per day. However, that may not be enough for you, depending on your activity level and the climate you live in. [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you have frequent headaches, fatigue, dizziness, nausea, don’t urinate often, pass dark or cloudy urine, and don’t sweat much, you are probably not getting enough water. [3] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Eat foods that have slight laxative effects and are high in fiber.
steps.content: Eat foods that have slight laxative effects and are high in fiber. Some of these, like prunes, have sorbitol. Sorbitol draws water into the stool, making it soft and easy to pass. [4] X Research source [5] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source [6] X Research source Prunes or prune juice Peaches Pears Plums Apples Apricots Raspberries Strawberries Beans Peas Spinach

steps.title: Eat more fiber.
steps.content: Eat more fiber. Fiber is the indigestible material in plant foods. Your body passes them through without absorbing them. This means that they help to produce soft, bulky stool which is easy to pass. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You need both water soluble fiber, which turns into a gel-like material in water, and insoluble fiber, which does not dissolve. Soluble fiber is found in oats, peas, beans, apples, citrus fruits, carrots, and barley. You can get insoluble fiber in whole-wheat flour, wheat bran, nuts, beans, and vegetables like cauliflower and green beans. Many plants have both soluble and insoluble fiber, you can get both by eating lots of different grains and vegetables. Eating more fiber will be most effective if you drink extra water to help dissolve the water soluble fiber.

steps.title: Maintain healthy gut bacteria by eating healthy foods like yogurt.
steps.content: Maintain healthy gut bacteria by eating healthy foods like yogurt. Your digestive tract needs the right balance of microbes to efficiently digest your food. When this microbe community gets out of balance, it can make you constipated and interfere with the absorption of nutrients. Live culture yogurt and other fermented dairy products like kefir can help restore and rebalance your gut bacteria. This can help you combat hard stools due to: [8] X Research source Irritable bowel syndrome Unexplained diarrhea and constipation Diarrhea or constipation after antibiotics have killed some of the naturally occurring gut bacteria

steps.title: Add supplements to your diet to promote healthy digestion.
steps.content: Add supplements to your diet to promote healthy digestion. But be sure to consult your doctor first because some supplements may change how your body processes some medicines. Try fiber supplements. They will make your stool bulkier, softer and easier to pass. These supplements are often called bulk-forming laxatives and you should try these before moving on to other types of laxatives. Look for ones with methylcellulose, psyllium, calcium polycarbophil, and guar gum as active ingredients (e.g., FiberCon, Metamucil, Konsyl, and Citrucel). [9] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Try probiotic supplements. Probiotics are bacteria and yeasts that are like your naturally occurring gut microbes. Taking probiotics may help if you are experiencing cycles of diarrhea and constipation. They may also help with IBS. [10] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Stimulate your bowels with a cup of coffee.
steps.content: Stimulate your bowels with a cup of coffee. Coffee can have a mild laxative effect, so adding a cup or two of coffee to your daily regimen may help to keep your bowels regular. [11] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you already drink coffee you may either need a bit more, or your body may be too habituated for it to provide relief.

steps.title: Reduce your intake of foods that may cause constipation.
steps.content: Reduce your intake of foods that may cause constipation. Many of these foods are low in fiber, but high sugar and fat. This causes you to feel full before you've eaten enough fiber. Examples include: [12] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source [13] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Milk and cheese Squash Sugary foods like pastries, puddings, candy and cake Fatty meats [14] X Research source

steps.title: Eat many small meals rather than only a few large ones.
steps.content: Eat many small meals rather than only a few large ones. [15] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Eating regularly will provide your digestive tract with continuous, low level stimulation and promote healthy digestion and regular contractions. Eat slowly to give your body time to process your food. Eating too fast makes you more likely to overeat, overwhelming your digestive system. Chew your food thoroughly to promote easy digestion and moderate portion sizes.

steps.title: Exercise for at least 30 minutes per day.
steps.content: Exercise for at least 30 minutes per day. Exercise will stimulate your bowels to contract, moving food through your system. [16] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The activity should be strenuous enough to increase your heart rate like fast walking, swimming, running, or biking. Sometimes this works surprisingly quickly. Plan a route with frequent bathrooms available! If you have other health concerns that might make exercise inadvisable, talk to your doctor first.

steps.title: Reduce stress in your life.
steps.content: Reduce stress in your life. Stress has been shown to cause constipation and diarrhea, both of which may accompany hard, dry stools. Try relaxation techniques such as: [17] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Deep breathing Yoga Meditation Tai chi Massage Listening to relaxing music Visualizing relaxing locations Progressive muscle relaxation where you go through your body and deliberately tense and release each muscle group

steps.title: Give yourself time on the toilet after each meal.
steps.content: Give yourself time on the toilet after each meal. You can simultaneously do relaxation techniques to promote movement through your system. [18] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source [19] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Spend at least 10 minutes on the toilet approximately 30 minutes after eating. Put your feet on a low stool, so your knees are above your hips. This may make the bowel movement easier.

steps.title: Use biofeedback to learn to release your pelvic floor muscles.
steps.content: Use biofeedback to learn to release your pelvic floor muscles. This can help you learn more about how you pass bowel movements. [20] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The therapist will use a machine to measure the tension in your rectum and help see how your muscles function when passing a bowel movement. Go to a therapist who works with a doctor or is recommended by your doctor to be sure that they are reliable.

steps.title: Consult your doctor.
steps.content: Consult your doctor. Some prescription medications can cause constipation, such as opioid pain relievers. Your doctor may recommend changing your medication or adding a laxative to counter constipation. Your doctor may recommend either over-the-counter medicines or prescribe something stronger. See your doctor right away if you have: [21] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Rectal bleeding Severe weight loss Fatigue Severe abdominal pain

steps.title: Lubricate your bowels with a small amount of mineral oil.
steps.content: Lubricate your bowels with a small amount of mineral oil. Consult your doctor to determine what the right dose is for you. Wait at least two hours after eating because it may prevent you from fully absorbing the nutrients. It will work within the next six to eight hours. Do not take it while lying in bed, because if you accidentally inhale some of it, it can cause pneumonia in your lungs. For this reason, do not give it to children younger than seven. Do not take mineral oil if you are pregnant, as it may prevent the uptake of nutrients and cause bleeding in the newborn if taken for a long time.

steps.title: Try stool softeners.
steps.content: Try stool softeners. These medications take moisture out of the intestines and use it to make your stool wetter. Common ones include Colace and Surfak. Drink an extra few glasses to water each day when you take them.

steps.title: Use osmotic laxatives to make your stool wetter.
steps.content: Use osmotic laxatives to make your stool wetter. These medications work by generating more liquid in your intestines. This will also stimulate your intestines to contract and move stool along, though it may take a few days. Common ones include: [22] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source [23] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Macrogol Lactulose Polyethylene glycol (MiraLax)

steps.title: Consider stimulant laxatives.
steps.content: Consider stimulant laxatives. These are useful if your stool is soft enough to pass, but your intestines aren’t contracting to move it through. These medications stimulate contractions and should work within 12 hours. Common ones are: [24] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Senna Bisacodyl Sodium Picosulphate

steps.title: Remove a fecal impaction.
steps.content: Remove a fecal impaction . If your rectum is blocked with hard, dry stool, you can get relief from a suppository, enema, or manual disimpaction. [25] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source [26] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source A suppository is a capsule of medication that you put in your anus where it dissolves and is absorbed. An enema is a liquid medication that is introduced into the large intestine via the anus. This should be done by the doctor. Manual disimpaction requires your doctor or nurse to put on gloves and insert two lubricated fingers into the rectum to break up and remove impacted feces. [27] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source
